text:
Luke Lavis: Janelia is amazing because it's
basically what every first-year graduate student
wishes academia was.

Manny Morone: This is Janelia Research Campus
in scenic Ashburn, Va., a part of Howard Hughes

Medical Institute that studies how the brain
does what it does.

Here, a lean—but totally not mean—team
of chemists led by Luke Lavis brew up cutting-edge

molecular tools for the biological researchers
on campus—and for even more neuroscientists
around the world.

What Lavis loves about Janelia—what he was
talking about earlier—is that the institution
values practical, usable science over science that races to be first at achieving a new goal.

And according to him, those values can be
flipped in academic settings.

At Janelia, Lavis recently became the overseer
of molecular toolmaking for imaging experiments.

What that means is his team develops very
useful molecules—both proteins and synthetic

compounds—for very specific tasks, hence
the molecular tool moniker.

Lavis: In this environment at Janelia where
you have a bunch of biologists who have specific
questions, chemists have this ability to design a molecule that can actually do what they want.

Manny: Those biology questions could be “Can
you make a sensor for some signaling molecule
in a cell?”

Or “Can you tweak this molecule to make
it show up a bit brighter under a microscope?”

Lavis’s group specializes in making molecules
that can be put in living cells—like neurons—and

then triggered to reveal what those cells
are doing.
One type of molecule that’s in high demand at Janelia is Lavis’s set of fluorescent dyes.

Every day someone uses these molecules in
tiny sensor systems to make new discoveries
about the brain.

So he took us around Janelia to see what people
are doing with ’em.

Here's a neuron that’s expressing a protein
construct
that can grab one of Lavis's fluorescent dyes.

It's under a microscope that can see the glow
of the protein-dye combo.

Because the dyes emit fluorescent light at
certain voltages, when a neuron fires, researchers

can track each electrical impulse running
down the neuron by just looking at how bright
the cells are.

Seeing single neurons firing has provided
information about how they fundamentally work.

You can take that one step further and use
voltage-triggered dyes in a population of

cells to see how a bunch of neurons form networks
and talk to each other.

What’s even crazier is that biologists at
Howard Hughes can use the dyes to watch electrical

signals travel through a live brain in real
time.

Right now, they’re working mainly with the
brains of zebrafish and flies.
The word “brainstorm” comes to mind.

To make their molecules, Lavis and his team
take dyes like fluorescein, which has been

around for, like, 100 years, and make related
molecules that shine brighter, are more stable,

and let you keep tabs on more cells than similar
dyes on the market.

Even though this approach is really effective,
Lavis isn’t convinced it would have been
possible outside Janelia.

That’s because in a usual academic chemistry
department, you have to publish a lot of papers
in journals to get tenure.

And journals can often care more about being
novel—being first to achieve something—than
being practical.
Lavis: And here Janelia is the opposite.

We really want to build tools that people
can use.

And so the mark of success is not how many
papers we get but how many people are using
the molecules that we make.

Manny: The irony is that even though Lavis
isn’t doing flashy chemistry, other research
groups are taking notice.

Lavis gets requests for dyes from all around
the U.S. and overseas.

At this point, Janelia has sent out thousands
of vials of Lavis’s molecular sensors.

Just while we were talking to him, four people
hit him up for some dyes.

Lavis: The most fun is when it's like a postdoc
who, you know, has been trying to do an experiment

and they just don't have enough photons or
the thing isn't bright enough.

And so they're like, “If I could only, you
know—if I can only get something slightly

brighter I can actually do my experiment and,
you know, publish my paper.

So it is kind of a fun thing to be in essence
the dye Santa or the dye fairy or whatever
you want to call it to the world.

Manny: If you’re a researcher and think
you could use a bit of the—I guess—world-famous

Janelia Fluor dyes, you can contact Lavis
for some samples.

Also, if you’re in a frenzy for more footage
of fluorescent compounds, check out the Instagram

of Claire Deo, a postdoc in Lavis’s lab,
where she documents some of the colorful research
they do day in and day out.

And of course, if you’re feeling up to it,
subscribe to our YouTube channel.

I can’t promise any dyes, but, maybe some
cool videos.
I mean I think they’re cool, so …
